ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence (SSCD)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Indicated by Tullio phenomenon, Hennebert sign, autophony, low-frequency conductive loss with preserved acoustic reflexes, and presence of cVEMP responses.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Perilymphatic Fistula
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Can present with pressure-induced vertigo (Hennebert sign) and hearing loss, but less likely to show the specific 'third window' audiometric pattern.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Ménière's Disease
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Causes episodic vertigo and low-frequency hearing loss, but typically sensorineural rather than conductive, and does not present with sound-induced vertigo.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Otosclerosis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Causes low-frequency conductive hearing loss but is typically associated with absent acoustic reflexes, unlike the preserved reflexes seen here.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing thresholds and identify any air-bone gaps.
To evaluate speech reception and word recognition abilities.
To assess middle ear function and tympanic membrane mobility.
To check for retrocochlear pathology and middle ear muscle reflexes; preservation in conductive loss is a key sign of SSCD.
To test for pressure-induced nystagmus (Hennebert sign) indicative of a third window lesion.
To evaluate vestibular function and rule out peripheral vestibular hypofunction.
To assess saccular function; presence of response despite conductive loss suggests SSCD.
High-resolution imaging to visualize the bone overlying the superior semicircular canal.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Audiometry revealed a mild low-frequency conductive hearing loss in the left ear with significant air-bone gaps. Paradoxically, acoustic reflexes were present at normal levels, and tympanometry was normal Type A. The patient reported dizziness during tympanometry and reflex testing, suggesting sound/pressure sensitivity.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear normal. Left ear mild conductive loss at 250-500 Hz with air-bone gaps (~35 dB at 250 Hz, ~25 dB at 500 Hz), rising to normal at 1000-8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal SRTs (RE 8 dB, LE 10 dB) and excellent WRS (100% bilaterally).

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Normal Type A bilaterally. Patient reported becoming 'slightly dizzy' during left ear testing.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Present at normal levels bilaterally (85-95 dB HL) despite left conductive loss. Patient reported dizziness and tilted left during stimulation.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Neurotology examination confirmed pressure-induced vestibular symptoms consistent with a superior canal dehiscence.

tests.name: Office Examination (Valsalva)
tests.result_summary: Nose-pinch Valsalva evoked downbeating torsional nystagmus (fast-phase clockwise), suggesting superior semicircular canal involvement.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Vestibular testing showed normal VNG results but confirmed the presence of cVEMP responses in the left ear despite the conductive hearing loss, which is diagnostic for SSCD.

tests.name: Videonystagmography (VNG)
tests.result_summary: Normal oculomotor, positional, and caloric results. No significant unilateral weakness (7% left) or directional preponderance.

tests.name: cVEMP
tests.result_summary: Responses present bilaterally. Left amplitude larger than right (though asymmetry ratio 23% considered normal). Presence of cVEMP despite conductive loss is the critical finding.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Imaging provided anatomical confirmation of the diagnosis.

tests.name: CT Scan
tests.result_summary: Revealed dehiscence (absence of bone) overlying the left superior semicircular canal.

proposed_items: Surgical repair (plugging or resurfacing of the superior canal)
Avoidance of triggers (loud sounds, straining) if surgery is declined
counseling_actions: Explain the 'third window' mechanism causing sound/pressure energy to leak into the vestibular system
Clarify that the hearing loss is not due to middle ear pathology despite the 'conductive' pattern
Discuss surgical options versus conservative management based on symptom severity

escalation.rationale_short: Referral for medical evaluation and CT imaging to confirm suspected Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor resolution of vertigo, hyperacusis, and tinnitus, and assess vestibular compensation.

expected_outcome: Patient underwent a plugging procedure for her left SSCD and received vestibular therapy.
At 3 months post-surgery, patient reported marked improvement in vertigo, hyperacusis, and pulsatile tinnitus.
